Dear Tia Cobb:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the violations
identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is
due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. In
any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Title & (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
1

Section perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
Description rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff gave youth the keys to unlock their door. The door to the
control station of the unit is often left unlocked and opened. Staff
will often leave youth on the unit unsupervised.
Additional allegations were provided during an interview with
Youth A on 8/8/24:
On 8/5/24, Youth A was in an altercation with another youth, and
no staff intervened.
Investigation INTERVIEWS:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 8/6/24.
Complainant did not have any additional information surrounding
the allegations.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 8/8/24. CA reported she didn’t hear about a situation
regarding Staff 1 giving Youth A her keys during a shift. CA
reported the door to the control room on the pod automatically
shuts and locks, but staff must ensure it latches. CA reported on
8/5/24, Youth A and other youth on the pod got into a physical
altercation, but Youth A was not knocked out. CA reported Youth
A was assessed by medical afterwards, and there were no follow-
up concerns.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/8/24.
Youth A reported one day last week (couldn’t remember when),
Staff 1 gave him her keys because he asked her to unlock his
door and Staff 4 did not have keys to do so. Youth A reported
Staff 4 was at the door to the control room and Staff 1 was seated
at the table on the pod when it occurred.
Youth A reported the control room door doesn’t shut automatically,
so staff are always leaving it open and unattended. Youth A could
not provide any specific details regarding times of day, dates, or
staff involved. Youth A reported there are times when youth are
unsupervised on the pod completely, but it mostly happens when
staff go into the control room and there are no staff on the pod.
Youth A reported a lot of things could happen to youth (i.e. self-
harm, physical altercations, etc.) when staff go into the control
room and leave the pod unattended. Youth A reported although
nothing has happened yet, the possibility of it makes him feel
uncomfortable and unsafe.
2

Youth A reported on 8/5/24, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D were
all fighting him because he was putting food and water into the
wall speaker on the pod because he was angry. Youth A reported
they hit him so hard, he got knocked out and everything went
black. Youth A reported he got lumps on his head and couldn’t
move. Youth A reported Staff 3 was the only staff present on the
unit, and she was just sitting down watching it happen. Youth A
reported Staff 3 did not intervene in the fight or say “stop”, and
instead, encouraged it and said, “go get him”. Youth A reported he
thinks there should always be two staff on each pod, but a lot of
times there’s only one staff present.
An attempt was made to interview Youth B face to face at the
facility on 8/8/24, but he refused to talk or provide any
information.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/8/24.
Youth C reported he wasn’t present for the altercation between
Youth A and Youth B on 8/5/24 because he was in his room at the
time. Youth C reported he heard Staff 3 call for back-up on the
walkie-talkie. Youth C reported he also heard Staff 3 yelling, “stop,
stop, leave him alone”, and heard her tell the other youth not to
get involved. Youth C reported the control room door is never left
open and unattended. Youth C reported the control room door
shuts mostly on its own, but then staff must ensure its latched
closed before it automatically locks. Youth C reported youth are
never left on the pod unsupervised. Youth C reported he has
never seen any staff give their keys to any youth.
Youth D was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/8/24.
Youth D reported he thinks the ratio for staff to youth is 1:4 or 1:5.
Youth D reported they have eight youth on the pod, and during the
morning shift they consistently have two staff, but in the
afternoon/evening shifts, they sometimes only have one staff.
Youth D reported there are a lot of problems with the youth on the
pod, so a lot of staff don’t want to work on the pod, which leaves
them short staffed. Youth D reported the only time he would
consider the pod to be unsupervised is when there’s only one staff
working, and the staff goes into the control room to get something.
Youth D reported the control room door is never left open or
unattended unless a staff is in the control room or in the doorway
to the control room getting something quickly. Youth D reported
one day (couldn’t remember when), a staff (couldn’t remember
who) entered the control room to get water for a youth, and when
they exited, Youth A pushed past the staff to enter the control
3

room. Youth D reported the staff immediately escorted Youth A
out of the control room.
Youth D reported he was present when Youth A asked Staff 1 for
her staff keys. Youth D reported Staff 1 wasn’t looking at who
asked for the keys, had her finger through the key ring, and went
to hand her keys to Youth A. However, Youth D reported Staff 1
realized she was handing her keys to Youth A at the last minute,
and immediately snatched them back away from him. Youth D
reported Youth A said, “I was just trying to help because Staff 4
asked for the keys to let Youth B in his room”. Youth D reported
Youth A clearly wasn’t trying to help and was just looking for an
opportunity to intercept the keys.
Youth D reported on 8/5/24, a fight occurred between Youth A and
Youth B, and the only staff present at the time was Staff 3. Youth
D reported Youth A was antagonizing everyone on the unit. Youth
D reported Youth A threw a chair up at the ceiling, and when it
dropped, Youth B took the chair away so Youth A couldn’t do it
again. Youth A was mad Youth B took the chair away, so he
kicked Youth B in the leg. Youth A then threw his food and juice all
over the pod, causing a big mess. Youth D reported Youth A was
also smashing food, toothpaste, and liquid into the speakers on
the wall. Youth D reported he tried to de-escalate the situation as
a peer mentor by verbal encouragement, but Youth A wouldn’t
listen. Youth D reported Youth A took a marker and drew all over
the walls, doors, etc. Youth D reported when Youth A got to Youth
B’s door and started drawing on it, Youth B became really upset.
Youth D reported Youth A attempted to physically assault Youth
B, and then Youth B retaliated by hitting Youth A approximately
five times before the fight was broken up. Youth D reported Staff 3
is older and moves a little slower, but she got up and tried to
intervene as soon as she could.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 8/8/24.
Staff 1 reported her memory is terrible, but she knows for a fact
she never gave her keys to Youth A. Staff 1 reported she doesn’t
remember Youth A asking for her keys or even trying to take her
keys. Staff 1 reported on 8/7/24, Youth A talked to her about her
giving him her keys and told her she gave him the keys because
she was in a rush. Staff 1 reported she was confused because
she didn’t remember anything like that happening. Staff 1 reported
she didn’t remember a situation happening as Youth D outlined in
his interview either. Staff 1 reported if a youth asked her to open
his room, she would have done it herself and not tried to pass the
task onto another staff.
4

Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 9/5/24. Staff 2 reported he
has never seen the control room door left open and unlocked, and
he has never seen the youth on the unit unsupervised.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 9/10/24. Staff 3 reported if
there is only one staff on the unit, and that staff must go into the
control room to get something, the youth on the pod are
technically unsupervised because the staff is in a different room
than the youth. Staff 3 reported until about 1-2 weeks ago, she
worked on the pod alone often, and she would go into the control
room quickly if she needed to get things for youth. Staff 3 reported
the youth tend to swarm the control room when a staff is in there
and the staff don’t shut the door when they’re in the control room
or in the doorway, especially if there’s only one staff working at the
time. Staff 3 reported it is not a great process, and if a staff is
working alone, they should try to avoid going into the control room
as much as possible for the sake of safety of the youth.
Staff 3 reported on 8/5/24, Youth A dumped his lunch and drink all
over the unit, and then began drawing on the pod doors with a
marker. Staff 3 reported Youth A and Youth B then got into a
physical altercation. Staff 3 reported she was working alone, so
she called for staff backup over the walkie-talkie. Staff 3 reported
she remembers Youth A being the aggressor towards Youth B
and does not remember Youth B punching Youth A multiple times.
Staff 3 reported when the altercation began, she got up from her
chair and said, “stop guys”, and walked over to intervene. When
Staff 3 was informed the video footage does not show her
intervening and does not show Youth A being the aggressor, she
continued to state the video is not how she remembered the
situation occurring. Staff 3 reported when there are two staff
present on the pod, typically one staff would try to de-escalate the
situation while the other staff put the other youth in their rooms to
help with the de-escalation. Staff 3 reported since she was
working alone, she did not feel comfortable physically intervening,
and she felt it was impossible to physically intervene without
additional consequences (i.e. restraining one youth, but the other
youth continuing to fight or Staff 3 getting in between the two
youth, and getting physically injured by the youth). Staff 3 reported
she did her best to de-escalate the situation, and then waited for
back-up to arrive. Staff 3 reported she believes there should
always be at least two staff working on every pod.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 9/5/24. Staff 4 reported
when staff are working, they normally share a set of keys because
5

they don’t have enough keys for all staff. Staff 4 reported one day
in the last month or so (couldn’t remember when), Youth A came
to her on the pod, handed her a set of staff keys and said, “Here’s
a set of keys, and because I like you, I’m going to give them to
you”. Staff 4 reported she was very upset because no youth on
the pod should have staff keys. Staff 4 reported she took the keys
from Youth A and said, “why do you have these?”. Staff 4 reported
she didn’t see a staff pass the keys to Youth A, but Youth A told
her Staff 1 gave him her keys. Staff 4 reported she talked to Staff
1 after the incident and told her she shouldn’t have given Youth A
her keys. Staff 4 reported Staff 1 did not provide any explanation
or take responsibility for her actions. Staff 4 reported Staff 1
simply stuttered a bit, acted appalled and looked like she was
“caught”. Staff 4 reported she told Supervisor about the incident
after it occurred. Staff 4 reported she hasn’t heard or seen any
issues regarding the control room door being left open, or youth
being unsupervised on the pod.
Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 9/9/24. Staff 5 reported
she has seen the control room door left open and the pod left
unsupervised on multiple occasions, but she was unable to
provide specific details on dates, times, or staff involved. Staff 5
reported there have been times when they are short staff where
she has had to go into the control room to get a youth’s property
box. Staff 5 reported being short staffed around shower time and
getting the youths’ hygiene boxes from the control room is
especially difficult. Staff 5 reported when she is the only staff
working, but is in the control room, technically there are no staff on
the pod, which leaves the youth unsupervised. Staff 5 reported the
pod is not in direct line of sight, but staff can still see youth from
the control room. Staff 5 reported for safety of the youth, and
according to facility policy, they’re supposed to always be in line of
sight.
Staff 6 was interviewed via phone on 9/5/24. Staff 6 reported
there are usually two staff working each shift, so the youth are
never left unsupervised. Staff 6 reported the control room door is
not supposed to be left open because there are items in there the
youth cannot have without permission (i.e. snacks, phones, writing
utensils, food, access to the adjoining pod, etc.). Staff 6 reported
the only time the control room door might be left open is when a
staff is in the control room doorway getting something out of the
control room for a youth.
Supervisor was interviewed via phone on 9/9/24. Supervisor
reported the information regarding Youth A having a staff’s keys
6

was passed onto him in passing by Staff 4. Supervisor admitted
he didn’t fully understand the situation Staff 4 presented to him
and didn’t ask additional questions as he was busy with more
pressing emergencies at the facility. Supervisor admitted he did
not follow-up afterwards to learn more about what happened, and
he did not have a conversation with Staff 1 surrounding the
situation. Supervisor reported he hasn’t seen or heard of any
issues with the control room door being open or staff leaving youth
unsupervised on the pod.
VIDEO REVIEWED:
Video footage from 8/5/24 was reviewed. Youth A is seen on the
pod with a marker in his hand, drawing on a door on the pod. He
exchanges words with someone off camera. Youth B enters the
camera frame and approaches Youth A. Youth B says, “I’m not
gonna just let you do that bro”. Youth A faces Youth B, holding the
marker in one hand and puts his other arm up in a defensive
position. Youth B gets closer to Youth A and punches him 15
times, mostly hitting Youth A on his back and back of his head.
After Youth B punches Youth A, Youth B backs off, and then a
female staff is heard on the walkie-talkie requesting for security
back-up. Two other youth are on the sidelines watching, but do
not engage in the altercation. No staff are present on the video
intervening in the altercation. No staff are heard telling Youth B to
stop or attempting to de-escalate the situation.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Youth Discipline and Behavior Modification Policy states
physical management procedures are an appropriate staff
response and justified to separate youth in a physical fight.
• The facility does not have a policy regarding staff keys.
• Statement of Youth and Family Rights states a youth has
the right to receive appropriate adult supervision, support,
and guidance.
• Youth Supervision policy states proper supervision of youth
is necessary to ensure youth and staff safety and to
prevent escape. Staff are always responsible for the
supervision and ongoing safety and security of youth.
Youth may never be left unattended or unsupervised by
staff. Staff may never do anything to jeopardize the safety,
care, or welfare of youth. Staff shall maintain within
continuous “line-of-sight supervision” when youth are
outside of their rooms. Line-of-sight supervision is defined
7

as “coordinating activities of the residents, under your
supervision, so visible contact is maintained, and the
actions of the residents are always under observation.”
Staff shall monitor youth closely to assess the need for de-
escalation and/or the agency’s therapeutic crisis
intervention model.
• Staff 1 does not have any disciplinary actions in her
employee file. Staff 1 completed training regarding
appropriate use of staff keys during orientation on 6/28/24
and 7/3/24.
• Staff 3 has 50 disciplinary action plans in her employee file;
45 of which are unrelated to concerns in this investigation.
However, 5 disciplinary actions contain similar concerns as
this investigation:
o Sept. 2018 – Staff 3 failed to abide by safety
rules/policies by going into the control room when a
youth was “off focus”, which resulted in the youth
attacking a peer. Staff 3 failed to assist a coworker
during the incident, so the youth also attacked the
coworker. Staff 3 failed to intervene to assist her
coworker.
o March 2018 – Staff 3 failed to maintain line of sight
supervision on youth and didn’t intervene
appropriately during a youth’s assault on a peer.
o July 2017 – Staff 3 failed to intervene in 3 youth
assaulting a peer.
o March 2005 & February 2007 – Failed to maintain
“line-of-sight” supervision of youth.
Staff 3 received Crisis Intervention – Verbal De-escalation
training on 2/15/24, Crisis Intervention – Handle with Care
Physical Practicum on 3/14/24, Child Management
Techniques/Discipline Techniques on 5/16/24, and Youth
Supervision departmental training on 1/5/24 & 5/22/24.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, video reviewed, and documentation reviewed, Staff 3
did not intervene using physical management or verbal de-
escalation when Youth B physically assaulted Youth A. Staff 3 did
not call for security back-up until after the altercation was over.
In addition, based on youth and staff interviews, staff have failed
to comply with “line-of-sight” supervision policy requirements when
going into the control room while working alone.
8

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was provided to the facility to address staff
keys in a new or existing policy to ensure staff understand the
requirements surrounding their possession and use. Also, the
facility should consider having two staff always working on each
pod to ensure safety of staff and youth.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR #2023C0000468 dated 6/28/23; CAP approved 8/15/23
SIR #2023C0000424 dated 6/7/23; CAP approved 7/10/23
SIR #2023C0000450 dated 6/7/23; CAP approved 7/5/23
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title & (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Section policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
Description intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff pulled Youth A by his shirt and around his waist to stop him
from exiting the pod.
Investigation VIDEO FOOTAGE REVIEWED:
Video footage from 8/5/24 was reviewed. Staff 7 enters the pod
and Youth A is standing near the door. After Staff 7 enters, the
door closes slowly, and Youth A attempts to sneak behind Staff 7
to exit the pod through the door. Staff 7 turns and grabs Youth A’s
shirt to stop him from exiting. Staff 7 pulls Youth A back into the
pod by his shirt, and then Staff 7 wraps his arms around Youth A’s
waist from behind and pulls him the rest of the way into the pod.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Discipline and Behavior Modification policy does not list
pulling a youth on any part of their body as an acceptable
or prohibited practice.
• Youth Supervision policy states staff must know and follow
the youth discipline, behavior management, and restraint
policies.
• Staff 7 does not have any disciplinary actions in his
employee file. Staff 7 was trained in Crisis Intervention –
Handle with Care Physical Practicum on 3/14/24. Staff 7
was trained on Child Management Techniques/Discipline
Techniques on 5/16/24.
9

Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per video reviewed,
Staff 7 pulled Youth A by his shirt and around his waist to stop him
from exiting the pod. In addition, the facility’s policy does not
address the subsection of this rule as a prohibited practice.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered to the facility to update their
Discipline & Behavior Modification policy to ensure it addresses all
aspects of the licensing restraint rules and their subsections as
outlined, prohibiting the specific items noted.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR #2023C0000787SI dated 12/19/23; CAP approved 2/2/24
SIR #2023C0000773SI dated 10/26/23; CAP approved 12/6/23
SIR #2023C0000650SI dated 9/8/23; CAP approved 9/20/23
SIR #2023C0000437 dated 6/7/23; CAP approved 7/10/23
Rule Code CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title & (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Section policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
Description intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv)Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth’s
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff cussed at Youth A.
Investigation VIDEO FOOTAGE REVIEWED:
Video footage with audio from 8/5/24 was reviewed. Staff 7 says
“Bro, what the fuck is wrong with you?” to Youth A after Youth A
attempts to hit Staff 7 and misses.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
• Youth Discipline and Behavior Modification Policy states
any type of verbal abuse, ridicule or humiliation is
prohibited.
• Youth Supervision policy states staff must know and follow
the youth discipline, behavior management, and restraint
policies.
• Prohibited Conduct Policy states unprofessional conduct
and use of abusive or threatening language by staff are
prohibited on company premises or during company time.
10

• Staff 7 does not have any disciplinary actions in his
employee file. Staff 7 was trained on Child Management
Techniques/Discipline Techniques on 5/16/24. Staff 7
received training on behavior management during a quality
program committee meeting on 7/9/24.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per video reviewed,
Staff 7 cussed at Youth A.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR #2024SIC0001352 dated 8/30/24; CAP pending
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
